TITLE: Inside Disney’s Succession Struggle and Bob Iger’s Return to Power
SUMMARY: The inside story of how Bob Iger undermined and outmaneuvered Bob Chapek, his chosen successor, and returned to power at Disney.

TITLE: Presidential Debate Will be Big Test for ABC
SUMMARY: ABC News is under a microscope as its journalists prepare to host one of the most scrutinized moments of the 2024 campaign.

TITLE: Boeing Reaches Tentative Deal With Union Workers to Avert Strike
SUMMARY: The proposed contract, if approved by union members on Thursday, includes a 25 percent raise over four years and a promise to build the next plane in the Seattle-Portland area.

TITLE: In Shanghai, Searching for Those in Search of Connection
SUMMARY: Every week, lonely retirees in the city gather in a public park — and an Ikea canteen — with one goal in mind: finding true love. Alexandra Stevenson shared their stories.

TITLE: Salmonella Outbreak Prompts Egg Recall by Wisconsin Farm
SUMMARY: Officials said 65 people in nine states have been infected in the outbreak, which has been traced to an egg farm. No deaths have been reported.

TITLE: How Telegram Became a Playground for Criminals, Extremists and Terrorists
SUMMARY: Drug dealers, scammers and white nationalists openly conduct business and spread toxic speech on the platform, according to a Times analysis of more than 3.2 million Telegram messages.

TITLE: How Russia Found Its Way Into America’s Conservative Media
SUMMARY: Federal prosecutors say Russia paid an American media company to push pro-Kremlin messages from social media influencers including Benny Johnson, Tim Pool and Dave Rubin.

TITLE: Low Interest Rates Pose Risks for Investors
SUMMARY: While rate cuts are welcome in much of the economy, they pose problems for risk-averse investors who relish high money market and bond yields.

TITLE: How to Handle the Delay in the Release of the FAFSA Form
SUMMARY: The student financial aid application is expected to be ready by Dec. 1, two months later than usual. Experts offer some tips on what to do in the meantime.

TITLE: What Is ‘Agentic’ AI? It Doesn’t Require a Human to Tell It What to Do
SUMMARY: So-called agentic artificial intelligence doesn’t require a human to tell it what to do. At least, that’s the idea.

TITLE: The Big Number: $3.8 Billion
SUMMARY: The amount offered by Nordstrom’s founding family to buy its namesake retailer.

TITLE: Starliner Capsule Returns, but Boeing’s Space Business Woes Remain
SUMMARY: The capsule, which returned without astronauts, and other space programs at Boeing have suffered many delays and cost overruns.

TITLE: Can the Business of Tennis Be Fixed?
SUMMARY: In an interview with DealBook, the U.S.T.A. chief Lew Sherr discussed the U.S. Open’s record attendance, the prospect of a new tennis league, and fighting with pickleball for court space.

TITLE: Mushroom-Laced Candy Recall Highlights F.D.A.’s Limited Safety Role
SUMMARY: More than 150 people were sickened from products sold at smoke and vape shops, providing evidence of the lax regulation of new food items.

TITLE: Clark Halstead, Real Estate Broker Who Broke the Mold, Dies at 83
SUMMARY: He employed audacious marketing campaigns to lift his agency into the top tier of New York firms representing luxury properties.

TITLE: A Trove of Words to Remember From a Master Obituary Writer
SUMMARY: The byline of Robert D. McFadden, who retired on Sunday, has been one of the most distinguished in the history of The Times. Here is a sampler of his artful obituaries.

TITLE: Morgan Stanley Is Fined for First Republic C.E.O.’s Stock Sales
SUMMARY: James Herbert was permitted to sell nearly $7 million of shares before First Republic Bank’s demise last year, Massachusetts regulators said.

TITLE: Michael Lerner, 81, Is Dead; Founder of a Combative Jewish Magazine
SUMMARY: His publication, Tikkun, was a leading voice for left-wing American Jews. His ideas about “the politics of meaning” were embraced by Hillary Clinton.

TITLE: Stock Slide as Investors Wrestle With Shifting Bets on Rate Cuts
SUMMARY: The stock market “can’t win” at the moment, said Andrew Brenner, head of international fixed income at National Alliance Securities. “Heads I lose, tails I lose.”

TITLE: Ted Drewes Jr., the Frozen Custard King of St. Louis, Dies at 96
SUMMARY: Celebrity chefs and politicians paid tribute to the man behind the extra-thick shake known as the concrete, an intrinsic part of St. Louis summers.

TITLE: How Elon Musk Is Influencing Donald Trump
SUMMARY: Their fast-evolving political friendship has become a potential minefield, as Mr. Musk’s sprawling businesses may present conflicts of interest if Mr. Trump is elected in November.

TITLE: White House Condemns Tucker Carlson Interview With Holocaust Revisionist
SUMMARY: Mr. Carlson’s guest on “Tucker on X” made a variety of false claims about the Holocaust and World War II.

TITLE: Oasis Fans Balked at High Ticket Prices. But Were They ‘Dynamic’?
SUMMARY: A regulator said it was opening an investigation into Ticketmaster’s actions, but the company disputed that “dynamic pricing” came into play.

TITLE: Carl Icahn, Activist Investor, Faces Intense Scrutiny From Wall Street
SUMMARY: The value of the 88-year-old activist investor’s company has fallen by nearly $20 billion. Mr. Icahn said that he was “absolutely not selling.”

TITLE: For the Fed, a Sign That the Job Market Is Cooling but Not Cracking
SUMMARY: Fed officials are hurtling toward a rate cut this month, but Friday’s jobs data left their options open on the size of that reduction.

TITLE: Trumponomics 2.0: Breaking Down Donald Trump’s Economic Plan
SUMMARY: Higher tariffs, lower taxes, and more of Elon Musk: The former president outlined his economic vision to an audience of business leaders. But questions abound.

TITLE: U.S. Blowback to Nippon Steel-U.S. Steel Merger Vexes Japan
SUMMARY: A looming decision in Washington to block Nippon Steel’s merger with U.S. Steel on national security grounds is raising sharp questions in Tokyo.

TITLE: Co-Hosts of N.B.A. Player Podcasts Have ‘Best Job on the Planet’
SUMMARY: For the friends of some famous athletes, hosting a show can mean a little money, some fame and a whole lot of work.

TITLE: U.S. Job Market Shifts to Lower Gear
SUMMARY: Employers added 142,000 jobs in August, fewer than economists had expected, and previous months were revised downward.

TITLE: Japan Tries to Reclaim Its Clout as a Global Tech Leader
SUMMARY: Japanese chip companies are tapping billions of dollars and collaborating with foreign firms as part of new government policies that look outward.

TITLE: 7-Eleven Rejects Takeover Bid From Big Canadian Chain
SUMMARY: Japan’s Seven & i Holdings, the operator of 7-Eleven, has rebuffed a buyout offer that would have been the largest foreign-led acquisition of a Japanese company.

TITLE: Telegram Founder Pavel Durov Defends App in First Comments Since Arrest
SUMMARY: Pavel Durov, held in France since last month, blamed “growing pains” for the company’s problems and pledged to make improvements.

TITLE: Larry Ellison Will Control Paramount After Skydance Merger
SUMMARY: An F.C.C. filing shows that companies affiliated with Mr. Ellison will own most of the voting interest currently held by Shari Redstone.

TITLE: 4 Big Airlines Face U.S. Inquiry Over Frequent Flier Programs
SUMMARY: The Transportation Department ordered American, Delta, Southwest and United to share more information about their rewards practices to ensure they are fair to consumers and rivals.

TITLE: Federal Judge Temporarily Blocks Another Pillar of Biden’s Student Debt Plan
SUMMARY: The plan would affect millions of borrowers struggling with runaway interest and others who were still paying off loans after decades. It was set to take effect this fall.

TITLE: OPEC Plus Delays Plan to Increase Oil Output
SUMMARY: OPEC Plus will extend its cuts until at least December. Demand has weakened, and other countries, including the United States, are expected to continue to increase production.

TITLE: Teenage E-Cigarette Use Drops to a 10-Year Low
SUMMARY: The percentage of middle and high school students reporting that they vaped tobacco products declined to about a third of the peak levels in 2019, a new survey shows.

TITLE: Trump Calls for an Efficiency Commission, an Idea Pushed by Elon Musk
SUMMARY: Donald Trump, in a speech in New York, said the commission would conduct a sweeping audit of the federal government and recommend “drastic reforms” for cutting waste.

TITLE: How Swing State Politics Are Sinking a Global Steel Deal
SUMMARY: As the Biden administration nears a decision to block the proposed acquisition of U.S. Steel, the debate over national and economic security is being dwarfed by presidential politics.

TITLE: Start-Up Investors Push Back Against Venture Capital’s Bigger-Is-Better Mantra
SUMMARY: A small but vocal group is forming new funds and taking new approaches to counter the swell of money into venture capital in recent years.

TITLE: Harris’s Capital Gains Tax Break
SUMMARY: The vice president has proposed raising the levy on capital gains, a break from President Biden’s economic agenda, as she tries to keep big donors and progressives on side.

TITLE: Tax Policy Becomes a Fault Line for Harris
SUMMARY: The vice president is relying on tax proposals as a way to show she is different from both President Biden and her Republican rival, Donald Trump.

TITLE: Job Hunting Is a Challenge for Recent College Grads
SUMMARY: Unemployment is still low, but job seekers are competing for fewer openings, and hiring is sluggish. That’s a big turnaround from recent years.

TITLE: BLS Data on Jobs and Consumer Prices Faces a Test of Trust
SUMMARY: The Bureau of Labor Statistics, which tracks prices and employment, faces scrutiny after several missteps. Some questions have gone unanswered.

TITLE: Why This Jobs Report Could Be the Most Pivotal One in Years
SUMMARY: It’s tough to overstate how much hinges on Friday’s employment update, from the path for interest rates to the economic outlook.

TITLE: Samples of Linda Deutsch’s Reporting on 50 Years of Sensational Trials
SUMMARY: Covering some of America’s most sensational trials, she produced urgent, pithy “ledes” in the best tradition of wire-service reporting. Here’s a sampler.

TITLE: How Partisan Media Covered Trump’s Arlington Visit
SUMMARY: Liberal outlets criticized Mr. Trump for turning his visit into a photo opportunity, while conservative ones falsely suggested the altercation never happened.

TITLE: Linda Deutsch, The A.P.’s Dean of Courtroom Reporting, Dies at 80
SUMMARY: Covering notorious trials, she offered readers an unvarnished view of the sordid side of celebrity, told through many of the country’s most riveting legal dramas.

TITLE: J. Richard Munro, Who Oversaw the Creation of Time Warner, Dies at 93
SUMMARY: As chief executive, he expanded Time Inc.’s offerings, fended off a hostile takeover and built the world’s largest media company.

TITLE: Boeing Starliner Set to Leave Space Station Without Crew
SUMMARY: The troubled spacecraft is scheduled to undock on Friday for a trip back to Earth while two NASA astronauts will stay in orbit.

TITLE: Biden Expected to Block U.S. Steel Takeover by Nippon
SUMMARY: The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States is expected to raise national security concerns about selling the iconic steel producer to Japan’s Nippon Steel.

TITLE: Las Vegas Places a Bet on a New Art Museum, With Help From L.A.
SUMMARY: The city agreed to give land to a museum championed by the casino magnate Elaine Wynn, which will be a partnership with the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

TITLE: Jim Riswold, Creator of ‘Bo Knows’ and Air Jordan Ads, Dies at 66
SUMMARY: His work for Nike — particularly commercials starring Michael Jordan and Spike Lee — blurred the line between advertising and entertainment.

TITLE: Nordstrom Family Offers $3.8 Billion to Buy Its Namesake Retailer
SUMMARY: The $23-per-share offer by the department store’s founding family comes as retailers struggle to navigate new shopping trends and costly real estate.

TITLE: Noel Parmentel Jr., Essayist, Polemicist and Apostate, Dies at 98
SUMMARY: A self-described “reactionary individualist,” he mentored Joan Didion and was credited with famously comparing Nixon to a used-car salesman.

TITLE: Iran Emerges as a Top Disinformation Threat in U.S. Presidential Race
SUMMARY: With a flurry of hacks and fake websites, Iran has intensified its efforts to discredit American democracy and possibly tip the race against former President Donald Trump.

TITLE: Trump Media Stock Price Down 70% From March Peak
SUMMARY: The stock price of the former president’s social media company has often moved in tandem with investor perception of his standing in the presidential race.

TITLE: TikTok Expands its Election Resources Ahead of November
SUMMARY: The company is an increasingly popular source of political news. It’s adding more content about how elections work and media literacy.

TITLE: Slowdown Déjà Vu Rattles the Markets
SUMMARY: Investors sent technology stocks and other assets tumbling on concerns that the U.S. economy could be headed for a hard landing.
